@DavidW___ @Quant_Bull @HoymeBrandon Chainlink can dominate the crypto & enterprise market, as it's network architecture is extremely flexible. Enterprises move very slow & aren't innovators. They copy standard design patterns established by innovators, so dominating the crypto market sets standards for enterprises.

@Quant_Bull @HoymeBrandon That's not true. Enterprises use open-source software all the time (e.g. Linux). Chainlink isn't a single oracle network with a set design. It contains any number of disparate oracle networks running in parallel which can be designed using different nodes, data, & design patterns

There has been concern around @chainlink dumping $LINK at a rate of 1m a week. To be honest, this is a good thing. The team is decentralising their portion of supply.  At this rate, it will take about ten years to get the remaining $LINK into circulation.  https://t.co/xCSpMQcP50

@DavidW___ @Quant_Bull @HoymeBrandon Chainlink provides the very same flexibility if not more. It's not a single oracle network, but an infinite number of oracle networks that can be run in parallel without cross dependencies and designed to their own specifications.

@Quant_Bull @HoymeBrandon You simply don't get it. Enterprises can run their own oracle nodes directly on Chainlink, in fact, many traditional API providers already do. Also, Chainlink is blockchain agnostic & API agnostic, so it inherently does multi-chain oracles and connects to any enterprise system.
